baseline_groups.claim_summary: Occupation-level technological change (increase in computer/software requirements) affects post-displacement earnings losses among displaced workers
baseline_groups.notes: Cross-sectional OLS with year and year-of-job-loss FE, weighted by DWS supplement weights, clustered at SOC-4 digit level. Three baselines: Table 3 Col 2 (main, with employment share control), Col 1 (without employment share), Col 3 (full-time only with renormalized treatment). The surface also planned Col 4/5 (Autor-Dorn occupation codes) as baselines but these were not coded as baseline rows. All 43 specifications have p > 0.05; the baseline coefficient is small and statistically insignificant (coef=0.015, p=0.756, N=220).

global_notes: Surface-driven run. One baseline group (G1) matches the pre-run surface. The surface listed 4 additional baseline specs (table3_col4_AD, table3_col5_AD_ft) using Autor-Dorn occupation codes, but these were not implemented as baseline rows. The rc/data/treatment/AD_occ_codes spec from the surface is also absent, likely due to data construction complexity. Critically, the baseline result itself is not statistically significant (p=0.756), and no specification in the entire run achieves significance at 5%. This means the robustness analysis documents consistent non-significance rather than robustness of a significant finding.
